S2Generator.utils._decomposition#

Created on 2025/09/16 19:21:36 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan/S2Generator

class S2Generator.utils._decomposition.MovingDecomp(window_size: int = 5, method: str = 'simple', sigma: int = 2, poly_order: int = 2, alpha: float = 0.4)[source]#

Bases: object

Moving Average decomposition.

The 1D signal is decomposed into two parts, trend and cycle, by sliding average. This method is very simple and very suitable for processing non-stationary time series data.

__init__(window_size: int = 5, method: str = 'simple', sigma: int = 2, poly_order: int = 2, alpha: float = 0.4) → None[source]#

The input signal is decomposed by sliding average to obtain the trend and cycle parts.

Parameters:

  • window_size – The window size of the sliding average decomposition is preferably an odd number

  • method – Sliding decomposition method, optional [“simple”, “weighted”, “gaussian”, “savgol”, “exponential”]

  • sigma – Standard deviation for Gaussian kernel (default is 2)

  • poly_order – Order of the polynomial used to fit the samples (default is 2)

  • alpha – Smoothing factor, range from 0 to 1 (default is 0.4)

fit_transform(signal: ndarray, methods_list: List[str] | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]#

Execute the moving average decomposition algorithm

Parameters:

  • signal – the input univariate or multivariate signal of 1D numpy ndarray

  • methods_list – If it is a multivariate signal or a multivariate time series, a different sliding average method needs to be used for the signal of each channel. This can be done by passing a string that matches the number of input signal channels to the variable.

Returns:

The trend and seasonality of the input signal.

static plot_decomposition(signal: ndarray, trend: ndarray, seasonality: ndarray, colors: List[str] | None = None) → Figure | None[source]#

Visualize the decomposition results of the input signal

Parameters:

  • signal – The input 1D signal of numpy ndarray

  • trend – The trend of the input 1D signal decomposed by Moving_Decomp

  • seasonality – The seasonality of the input 1D signal decomposed by Moving_Decomp

  • colors – The colors for plotting signal, trend and seasonality

Returns:

the figure of matplotlib for plotting

class S2Generator.utils._decomposition.STL(period: int, seasonal: int = 7, trend: int | None = None, low_pass: int | None = None, seasonal_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, trend_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, low_pass_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, robust: bool = False, seasonal_jump: int = 1, trend_jump: int = 1, low_pass_jump: int = 1)[source]#

Bases: object

Seasonal-Trend decomposition using LOESS (STL)

This code comes from [PySDKit](wwhenxuan/PySDKit) by [changewam](changewam).

RB C. STL: A seasonal-trend decomposition procedure based on loess[J]. J Off Stat, 1990, 6: 3-73.

STL uses LOESS (locally estimated scatterplot smoothing) to extract smooths estimates of the three components. The key inputs into STL are: (1) season - The length of the seasonal smoother. Must be odd. (2) trend - The length of the trend smoother, usually around 150% of season. Must be odd and larger than season. (3) low_pass - The length of the low-pass estimation window, usually the smallest odd number larger than the periodicity of the data.

__init__(period: int, seasonal: int = 7, trend: int | None = None, low_pass: int | None = None, seasonal_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, trend_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, low_pass_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, robust: bool = False, seasonal_jump: int = 1, trend_jump: int = 1, low_pass_jump: int = 1) → None[source]#

Initialize STL decomposer configuration

Parameters:

  • period – Seasonal period length (must be >= 2)

  • seasonal – Seasonal smoothing window size (odd, >=7)

  • trend – Trend smoothing window size (odd, >= period)

  • low_pass – Low-pass filter window size (odd, >= period)

  • seasonal_deg – Seasonal LOESS degree (0 or 1)

  • trend_deg – Trend LOESS degree (0 or 1)

  • low_pass_deg – Low-pass filter LOESS degree (0 or 1)

  • robust – Whether to use robust mode for outlier handling

  • seasonal_jump – Seasonal component calculation jump step (optimization)

  • trend_jump – Trend component calculation jump step (optimization)

  • low_pass_jump – Low-pass filter calculation jump step (optimization)

fit_transform(endog: ndarray, inner_iter: int | None = None, outer_iter: int | None = None) → STLResult[source]#

Perform STL decomposition and return results

Parameters:

  • endog – Time series to decompose (1D numpy array)

  • inner_iter – Number of inner loop iterations (None for default)

  • outer_iter – Number of outer loop iterations (None for default)

Returns:

STLResult object

S2Generator.utils._print_status module#

This module is used to register and print the status of data generation in real time. Our time series sampling process requires inputting the stimulus time series into a complex system. Complex systems have a domain of definition. When our stimulus time series falls outside the domain of the symbolic expression, we need to regenerate the data.

Created on 2025/08/23 12:20:15 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan

show_start(n_inputs_points: int, input_dimension: int, output_dimension: int, max_trials: int, input_normalize: str | None = 'z-score', output_normalize: bool | None = 'z-score', input_max_scale: float | None = 16.0, output_max_scale: float | None = 16.0, offset: Tuple[float, float] | None = None) → None[source]#

Prints basic information about real-time parameters during data generation.

Parameters:

  • n_inputs_points – The number of points of time series to generate.

  • input_dimension – The number of the input dimensions of time series to generate.

  • output_dimension – The number of the output dimensions of time series or symbol expression to generate.

  • max_trials – The maximum number of trials to generate and try.

  • input_normalize – Normalize the input time series, choice of ‘z-score’ or ‘max-min’ or None, defaults to ‘z-score’.

  • output_normalize – Normalize the output time series, choice of ‘z-score’ or ‘max-min’ or None, defaults to ‘z-score’.

  • input_max_scale – The scaling factor of the input time series to generate.

  • output_max_scale – The scaling factor of the output time series to generate.

  • offset – The offset mean and std for the input time series.

S2Generator.utils._tools module#

This file primarily contains utility functions, such as those for obtaining the current time, ensuring the existence of a specified directory, saving and loading S2 data, and performing two different normalization operations.

Created on 2025/08/23 17:09:18 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan/S2Generator

S2Generator.utils._tools.ensure_directory_exists(file_path: str) → str[source]#

Ensures the directory in the given file path exists, creating it if necessary.

This function handles both file paths and directory paths: - For file paths (ending with .npy, .npz, or .json), ensures the parent directory exists - For directory paths, ensures the directory itself exists

Parameters:

file_path – Complete path including filename or directory path

Returns:

Full path to the file that should be used for saving

S2Generator.utils._tools.fft(array: ndarray, axis: int | None = None, norm: str | None = 'backward') → ndarray[source]#

Performs a Fast Fourier Transform on the input time series data.

Parameters:

  • array – Input two-dimensional time series with [n_points, n_dims].

  • axis – Axis over which to compute the FFT. If not given, the last axis is.

  • norm – Normalization method to use. Can be “backward”, “forward” or “ortho”.

Returns:

The transformed results for the input time series in freq domain.

array – The results of the FFT.

Returns:

S2Generator.utils._tools.save_s2data(symbol: str | Node | NodeList, excitation: int | bool | float | ndarray, response: int | bool | float | ndarray, save_path: str | None = None) → bool[source]#

Saves S2 data (symbolic expressions and time series) to the specified location.

This function works with load_s2data to provide a complete save/load workflow. Supports multiple file formats (.npy, .npz) and handles directory creation.

Parameters:

  • symbol – Symbolic expression data generated by S2Generator (Node, NodeList, or str)

  • excitation – Input excitation time series data

  • response – Response time series data obtained from the system

  • save_path – Save location with two input options: - Directory path: data will be saved as ‘s2data.npz’ in this directory - Full file path: must end with .npy or .npz extension

Returns:

Boolean indicating success status of the save operation.

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance module#

This module replicates the similarity metric between time series datasets used in the paper “Measuring Time-Series Dataset Similarity using Wasserstein Distance.” (Paper address: https://www.arxiv.org/abs/2507.22189)

Created on 2025/08/22 11:20:58 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan/S2Generator

Check if input data is valid, for the data type and the shape of ndarray.

Parameters:

data – The input time series data in Numpy ndarray.

Returns:

True if the input data is valid.

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance.dataset_max_min_normalization(data: ndarray, epsilon: float | None = 1e-05) → ndarray | None[source]#

Apply the max-min normalization operation to multivariate time series datasets with the shape of [n_samples, n_length] in NumPy ndarray.

Parameters:

  • data – The time series dataset with shape [n_samples, n_length].

  • epsilon – The maximum absolute value to avoid division by zero.

Returns:

The max-min normalized dataset with shape [n_samples, n_length].

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance.plot_wasserstein_heatmap(distance_matrix: ndarray, dataset_list: List[str] | None = None, figsize: Tuple[float, float] | None = (6, 4), dpi: int | None = 300, fontsize: int | None = 8, cmap: str | None = 'coolwarm') → Tuple[Figure, Axes][source]#

The distance matrix formed by the Wasserstein distance between data sets is obtained through heat maps.

Parameters:

  • distance_matrix – The wasserstein distance matrix between time series datasets.

  • dataset_list – The list of dataset names.

  • figsize – The figure size, defaults to (6, 4).

  • dpi – The resolution of the figure, defaults to 300.

  • fontsize – The font size, defaults to 8.

  • cmap – The color mapping for the heatmap, defaults to “coolwarm”.

Returns:

The figure and axes objects, defaults to (plt.Figure, plt.Axes).

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance.time_series_to_distribution(data: ndarray) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]#

Convert the input multivariate time series dataset to a normal distribution.

Parameters:

data – The input multivariate time series dataset in NumPy ndarray with [n_samples, n_length] shape.

Returns:

The mean vector and covariance matrix of a multivariate time series dataset.

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance.wasserstein_distance(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, mean_weight: float | None = 0.5, covar_weight: float | None = 0.5, return_all: bool | None = False) → Tuple[Any, signedinteger[Any], Any] | None | float[source]#

The Wasserstein distance is used to measure the similarity between two datasets. “Measuring Time-Series Dataset Similarity using Wasserstein Distance.” (Paper address: https://www.arxiv.org/abs/2507.22189)

This method models the time series dataset as a multivariate normal distribution and uses the Wasserstein similarity metric to measure the distribution distance between datasets, thereby characterizing the similarity or difference between the datasets.

The Wasserstein distance is a metric that measures the distance between two probability distributions. This distance is widely used in optimal transmission problems, primarily to determine the minimum distance between two distributions by minimizing the coupling cost. The p-Wasserstein distance is defined as follows:

\(W_p (\mu, \nu) = \sideset{}{}{\mathrm{min}}_{\gamma \in \Gamma _{\mu, \nu}} \left ( \int \left \| x - y \right \| ^ p \gamma \left ( \mathrm d x, \mathrm d y \right ) \right ) ^ {1/p}\)

where \(\mu, \nu \in \mathbb R ^ d\) and math:Gamma denotes the coupled set of \(\mu\) and \(\nu\).

This paper focuses on the Wasserstein distance \(d_{\mathrm Ws}\) between two multivariate normal distributions \(\mathcal D_X\) and \(\mathcal D_Y\), which is defined as:

\(d^2_{\mathrm W _s} \left ( \mathcal D_X, \mathcal D_Y \right ) = \left \| \hat{\mathbf{\mu}}_X - \hat{\mathbf{\mu}}_Y \right \| ^ 2 + \mathrm{tr} \left ( \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_X + \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_Y - 2 \sqrt{\hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_X \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_Y} \right )\)

Where the first term measures the distance between the mean vectors, and the second term captures the difference between the covariance matrices. If two datasets are to be close to each other, they must not only have similar mean vectors, but also similar covariate matrices.

Parameters:

  • x – The first ndarray dataset in NumPy with [\(n_samples\), \(n_vars\), \(n_length\)].

  • y – The second ndarray dataset in NumPy with [\(n_samples\), \(n_vars\), \(n_length\)].

  • mean_weight – The weight of the second norm of mean vector.

  • covar_weight – The weight of the second norm of covariance matrix.

  • return_all – If True, return all the tuple of (Wasserstein distances, mean_value, covar_value).

Returns:

The Wasserstein distance between x and y.

S2Generator.utils._wasserstein_distance.wasserstein_distance_matrix(data_list: List[ndarray], mean_weight: float | None = 0.5, covar_weight: float | None = 0.5) → ndarray[source]#

Calculate the distances between multiple datasets in a list and form a distance matrix.

Parameters:

  • data_list – The ndarray dataset list in NumPy with [n_samples, n_vars, n_length].

  • mean_weight – The weight of the second norm of mean vector.

  • covar_weight – The weight of the second norm of covariance matrix.

Returns:

The Wasserstein distance matrix in for the input ndarray list.

See also

wasserstein_distance

S2Generator.utils.visualization module#

S2Generator.utils.visualization.create_symbol_figure(symbol: str | List[str], width: float, height: float, dpi: int | None = 300) → Tuple[Figure, Axes, List[Text]][source]#

Create a specific Figure object for visualization.

Parameters:

  • symbol – The symbolic expression data to be visualized.

  • width – The width of the drawn image may need to be adjusted multiple times.

  • height – The height of the drawn image. If it is None, it will be automatically specified by the algorithm.

  • dpi – The resolution of the visualization image.

Returns:

The figure and axes objects.

S2Generator.utils.visualization.plot_symbol(symbol: str | Node | NodeList, width: int | None = 20, height: int | None = None, dpi: int | None = 160, return_all: str | None = False) → Figure | Tuple[Figure, Axes, List[Text]][source]#

This function visualizes symbolic data. Since the input symbolic expression data varies, you may need to adjust the width multiple times in actual use.

Parameters:

  • symbol – The symbolic data to be visualized.

  • width – The width of the drawn image may need to be adjusted multiple times.

  • height – The height of the drawn image. If it is None, it will be automatically specified by the algorithm.

  • dpi – The resolution of the visualization image.

  • return_all – Whether to return all visualization information

Returns:

  • True: return (Figure, Axis, List[Text]),

  • False: return Figure.

S2Generator.utils.visualization.which_edges_out(artist: Text | Any, *, padding: int | None = 0) → Dict[str, bool][source]#

Determine which edges of the canvas the artist is outside.

Parameters:

  • artist – Additional safety margin in pixels (can be negative to indicate “almost outside”).

  • padding – number of pixels around the edge of the canvas.

Returns:

Returns a dict: {‘top’, ‘bottom’, ‘left’, ‘right’} -> True/False.

Module contents#

This module primarily houses tools and auxiliary functions or classes, including functions for converting string notation into Markdown syntax, normalizing time series data, obtaining the current time, saving and loading S2 data, and calculating and measuring the similarity between two time series datasets.

Created on 2025/08/3 00:01:56 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com

class S2Generator.utils.MovingDecomp(window_size: int = 5, method: str = 'simple', sigma: int = 2, poly_order: int = 2, alpha: float = 0.4)[source]#

Bases: object

Moving Average decomposition.

The 1D signal is decomposed into two parts, trend and cycle, by sliding average. This method is very simple and very suitable for processing non-stationary time series data.

fit_transform(signal: ndarray, methods_list: List[str] | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]#

Execute the moving average decomposition algorithm

Parameters:

  • signal – the input univariate or multivariate signal of 1D numpy ndarray

  • methods_list – If it is a multivariate signal or a multivariate time series, a different sliding average method needs to be used for the signal of each channel. This can be done by passing a string that matches the number of input signal channels to the variable.

Returns:

The trend and seasonality of the input signal.

static plot_decomposition(signal: ndarray, trend: ndarray, seasonality: ndarray, colors: List[str] | None = None) → Figure | None[source]#

Visualize the decomposition results of the input signal

Parameters:

  • signal – The input 1D signal of numpy ndarray

  • trend – The trend of the input 1D signal decomposed by Moving_Decomp

  • seasonality – The seasonality of the input 1D signal decomposed by Moving_Decomp

  • colors – The colors for plotting signal, trend and seasonality

Returns:

the figure of matplotlib for plotting

show_start(n_inputs_points: int, input_dimension: int, output_dimension: int, max_trials: int, input_normalize: str | None = 'z-score', output_normalize: bool | None = 'z-score', input_max_scale: float | None = 16.0, output_max_scale: float | None = 16.0, offset: Tuple[float, float] | None = None) → None[source]#

Prints basic information about real-time parameters during data generation.

Parameters:

  • n_inputs_points – The number of points of time series to generate.

  • input_dimension – The number of the input dimensions of time series to generate.

  • output_dimension – The number of the output dimensions of time series or symbol expression to generate.

  • max_trials – The maximum number of trials to generate and try.

  • input_normalize – Normalize the input time series, choice of ‘z-score’ or ‘max-min’ or None, defaults to ‘z-score’.

  • output_normalize – Normalize the output time series, choice of ‘z-score’ or ‘max-min’ or None, defaults to ‘z-score’.

  • input_max_scale – The scaling factor of the input time series to generate.

  • output_max_scale – The scaling factor of the output time series to generate.

  • offset – The offset mean and std for the input time series.

class S2Generator.utils.STL(period: int, seasonal: int = 7, trend: int | None = None, low_pass: int | None = None, seasonal_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, trend_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, low_pass_deg: Literal[0, 1] = 1, robust: bool = False, seasonal_jump: int = 1, trend_jump: int = 1, low_pass_jump: int = 1)[source]#

Bases: object

Seasonal-Trend decomposition using LOESS (STL)

This code comes from [PySDKit](wwhenxuan/PySDKit) by [changewam](changewam).

RB C. STL: A seasonal-trend decomposition procedure based on loess[J]. J Off Stat, 1990, 6: 3-73.

STL uses LOESS (locally estimated scatterplot smoothing) to extract smooths estimates of the three components. The key inputs into STL are: (1) season - The length of the seasonal smoother. Must be odd. (2) trend - The length of the trend smoother, usually around 150% of season. Must be odd and larger than season. (3) low_pass - The length of the low-pass estimation window, usually the smallest odd number larger than the periodicity of the data.

fit_transform(endog: ndarray, inner_iter: int | None = None, outer_iter: int | None = None) → STLResult[source]#

Perform STL decomposition and return results

Parameters:

  • endog – Time series to decompose (1D numpy array)

  • inner_iter – Number of inner loop iterations (None for default)

  • outer_iter – Number of outer loop iterations (None for default)

Returns:

STLResult object

S2Generator.utils.fft(array: ndarray, axis: int | None = None, norm: str | None = 'backward') → ndarray[source]#

Performs a Fast Fourier Transform on the input time series data.

Parameters:

  • array – Input two-dimensional time series with [n_points, n_dims].

  • axis – Axis over which to compute the FFT. If not given, the last axis is.

  • norm – Normalization method to use. Can be “backward”, “forward” or “ortho”.

Returns:

The transformed results for the input time series in freq domain.

S2Generator.utils.plot_wasserstein_heatmap(distance_matrix: ndarray, dataset_list: List[str] | None = None, figsize: Tuple[float, float] | None = (6, 4), dpi: int | None = 300, fontsize: int | None = 8, cmap: str | None = 'coolwarm') → Tuple[Figure, Axes][source]#

The distance matrix formed by the Wasserstein distance between data sets is obtained through heat maps.

Parameters:

  • distance_matrix – The wasserstein distance matrix between time series datasets.

  • dataset_list – The list of dataset names.

  • figsize – The figure size, defaults to (6, 4).

  • dpi – The resolution of the figure, defaults to 300.

  • fontsize – The font size, defaults to 8.

  • cmap – The color mapping for the heatmap, defaults to “coolwarm”.

Returns:

S2Generator.utils.save_s2data(symbol: str | Node | NodeList, excitation: int | bool | float | ndarray, response: int | bool | float | ndarray, save_path: str | None = None) → bool[source]#

Saves S2 data (symbolic expressions and time series) to the specified location.

This function works with load_s2data to provide a complete save/load workflow. Supports multiple file formats (.npy, .npz) and handles directory creation.

Parameters:

  • symbol – Symbolic expression data generated by S2Generator (Node, NodeList, or str)

  • excitation – Input excitation time series data

  • response – Response time series data obtained from the system

  • save_path – Save location with two input options: - Directory path: data will be saved as ‘s2data.npz’ in this directory - Full file path: must end with .npy or .npz extension

Returns:

Boolean indicating success status of the save operation.

S2Generator.utils.wasserstein_distance(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, mean_weight: float | None = 0.5, covar_weight: float | None = 0.5, return_all: bool | None = False) → Tuple[Any, signedinteger[Any], Any] | None | float[source]#

The Wasserstein distance is used to measure the similarity between two datasets. “Measuring Time-Series Dataset Similarity using Wasserstein Distance.” (Paper address: https://www.arxiv.org/abs/2507.22189)

This method models the time series dataset as a multivariate normal distribution and uses the Wasserstein similarity metric to measure the distribution distance between datasets, thereby characterizing the similarity or difference between the datasets.

The Wasserstein distance is a metric that measures the distance between two probability distributions. This distance is widely used in optimal transmission problems, primarily to determine the minimum distance between two distributions by minimizing the coupling cost. The p-Wasserstein distance is defined as follows:

\(W_p (\mu, \nu) = \sideset{}{}{\mathrm{min}}_{\gamma \in \Gamma _{\mu, \nu}} \left ( \int \left \| x - y \right \| ^ p \gamma \left ( \mathrm d x, \mathrm d y \right ) \right ) ^ {1/p}\)

where \(\mu, \nu \in \mathbb R ^ d\) and math:Gamma denotes the coupled set of \(\mu\) and \(\nu\).

This paper focuses on the Wasserstein distance \(d_{\mathrm Ws}\) between two multivariate normal distributions \(\mathcal D_X\) and \(\mathcal D_Y\), which is defined as:

\(d^2_{\mathrm W _s} \left ( \mathcal D_X, \mathcal D_Y \right ) = \left \| \hat{\mathbf{\mu}}_X - \hat{\mathbf{\mu}}_Y \right \| ^ 2 + \mathrm{tr} \left ( \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_X + \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_Y - 2 \sqrt{\hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_X \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_Y} \right )\)

Where the first term measures the distance between the mean vectors, and the second term captures the difference between the covariance matrices. If two datasets are to be close to each other, they must not only have similar mean vectors, but also similar covariate matrices.

Parameters:

  • x – The first ndarray dataset in NumPy with [\(n_samples\), \(n_vars\), \(n_length\)].

  • y – The second ndarray dataset in NumPy with [\(n_samples\), \(n_vars\), \(n_length\)].

  • mean_weight – The weight of the second norm of mean vector.

  • covar_weight – The weight of the second norm of covariance matrix.

  • return_all – If True, return all the tuple of (Wasserstein distances, mean_value, covar_value).

Returns:

The Wasserstein distance between x and y.

S2Generator.utils.wasserstein_distance_matrix(data_list: List[ndarray], mean_weight: float | None = 0.5, covar_weight: float | None = 0.5) → ndarray[source]#

Calculate the distances between multiple datasets in a list and form a distance matrix.

Parameters:

  • data_list – The ndarray dataset list in NumPy with [n_samples, n_vars, n_length].

  • mean_weight – The weight of the second norm of mean vector.

  • covar_weight – The weight of the second norm of covariance matrix.

Returns:

The Wasserstein distance matrix in for the input ndarray list.

See also

wasserstein_distance
